text:
So with all this chitter chatter about modelling data and probability prediction, I'm wondering where simpletons like me would get started on these approaches? What tools would you consider are essential? I'm not a complete dunce (some parts are missing!) but Google searches seem to muddy the waters even more and all these Greek symbols are...all Greek to me.
I've been experimenting with various strategies using nothing but market data, but am really struggling to find anything worth punting some real money. Truth is, I seem to be able to construct strategies very easily but _winning_ strategies are much harder to come by. And with you all saying that the last few months have been golden, I really do feel quite disheartened with the whole thing. :flushed:

elements.text:
So with all this chitter chatter about modelling data and probability prediction, I'm wondering where simpletons like me would get started on these approaches? What tools would you consider are essential? I'm not a complete dunce (some parts are missing!) but Google searches seem to muddy the waters even more and all these Greek symbols are...all Greek to me.
I've been experimenting with various strategies using nothing but market data, but am really struggling to find anything worth punting some real money. Truth is, I seem to be able to construct strategies very easily but
winning
strategies are much harder to come by. And with you all saying that the last few months have been golden, I really do feel quite disheartened with the whole thing.

text: Linear models is where I got started. Logistic regression for classification is a decent starter if you're looking at binary problems (<http://e.g.as|e.g.> win / no win) as it's a pretty transparent model (unlike something more black box like neural networks/trees etc). Linear regression for regression tasks (there are a variety of methods out there to implement such a model). Scikit learn has all the basic tools you need for all the stages of modelling; data cleaning, standardisation, model fitting and evaluation

elements.text: Linear models is where I got started. Logistic regression for classification is a decent starter if you're looking at binary problems (
e.g.

win / no win) as it's a pretty transparent model (unlike something more black box like neural networks/trees etc). Linear regression for regression tasks (there are a variety of methods out there to implement such a model). Scikit learn has all the basic tools you need for all the stages of modelling; data cleaning, standardisation, model fitting and evaluation

text: Even RenTech started with plain ol' linear models :)

elements.text: Even RenTech started with plain ol' linear models :)

text: Important thing is to understand the fundamental relationship between your inputs and the thin you're forecasting - i.e. no point fitting a linear model to predict y from X if fundamentally X doesn't have a linear relationship to y. And to evaluate on out-of-sample data to understand if your model can actually generalise well.

elements.text: Important thing is to understand the fundamental relationship between your inputs and the thin you're forecasting - i.e. no point fitting a linear model to predict y from X if fundamentally X doesn't have a linear relationship to y. And to evaluate on out-of-sample data to understand if your model can actually generalise well.

text: As many ppl will tell you, build your model with context and understanding of the relationship between your input and target - just shoving some data into an algorithm without any context will most likely lead you to a nonsensical model

elements.text: As many ppl will tell you, build your model with context and understanding of the relationship between your input and target - just shoving some data into an algorithm without any context will most likely lead you to a nonsensical model

text: Totally agree with this. While ML is great for certain things, learning some techniques concerned with statistical inference is a good start. Trouble is that the entry level of mathematics is quite high to get a handle on even logistic regression (personally never came across GLMs until postgraduate levels of study). True, you don't need to know the theory to bang together a model in R/Python/Matlab/whatever, but having some appreciation of what you are modelling and the underlying assumptions of the techniques you are using is very important. Yes you can use a multitude of ML/stats tools blindly in the black box sense, but knowing how to interpret what comes out of them. It is not always about p-values. Trouble is the bar for entry is quite high.

elements.text: Totally agree with this. While ML is great for certain things, learning some techniques concerned with statistical inference is a good start. Yes you can use a multitude of ML/stats tools blindly in the black box sense, but knowing how to interpret what comes out of them. It is not always about p-values. Trouble is the bar for entry is quite high.

text: But again, depends on what you are trying to predict - if you want to try and model a time series of market data, it is a very different beast to trying to estimate probability of a sporting outcome.

text: personally <@U016TGY3676> if you dont have an idea for a strategy (learning task) before using AI/ML its unlikely to magic something up especially as the guys have mentioned if you dont understand what its doing. I think <@UGV299K6H> gave some great advice about understanding market fundamentals. In my opinion the algorithm is always an after thought after you feel you have a solid idea (for which people wont hand to you as it will lead to them losing profit, after years of work).

text: Thanks all. That's certainly something to think about. I've not "studied form" for many years as I always assumed that most of the public information is built into the prices by many algorithms such as the ones you use and the various bookies... something I probably wouldn't be able to better. Manually, I'm actually quite good at picking winners/losers but that often revolves around knowledge of local trainers and other things like trainer/jockey combos, distance travelled to racecourse, local information (I have a friend who's a horse owner), etc. Automating this is not something I believe can be done without a lot of manual intervention.

text: Seriously though - after staring at the graphs I have a good think and try to understand what might be causing whatever I see, I look for a way to theorise the market's behaviour and then ways to test that theory. For me it's important to understand the mechanisms, I'm not happy with correlation I want causation or I don't buy it.

text: The choice of tool depends on what you want to do. As some of the big guns say, "simple" things make them profit. But for example, if you wanted to try and build a probability model for each runner in greyhound races, you are going to need identify the right tools for the job. Part of the problem is knowing what you want to analyse, then digging around and finding the right tool. Trouble with ML (and statistics for that matter) is that there are so many methods and techniques and it can be bewildering at times. And as has been mentioned before, even if you FIND the right tool, chances are that there are others out there with access to bespoke data that puts them way ahead of you.

text: Yes I agree but I think for some sports, such as football, the analytics available and the bespoke data around pretty much put the average "one man and his computer" way behind. Maybe for obscure leagues and markets like bookings/corners etc there is an edge to be obtained. I reckon even the man with the most sophisticated model in the world is going to be behind the guy with advance news of the team squad when it comes to profit making. Don't get me wrong, I am not downplaying ML/stats at all (I am/was a mathematician after all), I am just saying that to beat market prices in the bigger sports as a one man band going down the analytical route is a tough gig.

elements.text: Yes I agree but I think for some sports, such as football, the analytics available and the bespoke data around pretty much put the average "one man and his computer" way behind. Maybe for obscure leagues and markets like bookings/corners etc there is an edge to be obtained. I reckon even the man with the most sophisticated model in the world is going to be behind the guy with advance news of the team squad when it comes to profit making. Don't get me wrong, I am not downplaying ML/stats at all (I am/was a mathematician after all), I am just saying that to beat market prices in the bigger sports as a one man band going down the analytical route is a tough gig.

text: I think this also speaks to what people were discussing yesterday about stat driven vs market driven styles of play. The scale and sophistication of some of the stats driven outfits is unbelievable, very hard for a one man band to compete with. When you have football syndicates sending scouts to every game in Europe to gather and feed back bespoke data it's hard to beat that just in terms of data quality never mind analytics.

text: The thing is it's hard to formulate a nice way of saying _"I've done well at this and it's been great but I don't think you should waste too much time on it because the reality is that most people fail and it's far more likely that you'll be on that team than this one."_ Even though obviously that's the truth. So instead you answer the questions and try to help even though you know it's probably for nothing at best.

text: Sometimes you see a question and think _"yeah actually I don't think I'll give that away"_ and there are a few things that some people know about but don't talk about but then why should they? I've built my knowledge over more than a decade I'm not going to post it all up for the world to see for free. Even so there's still more valuable, honest and well founded advice given here than I think you can find anywhere else.

text: I don't use any of those things. In market based operations I just look for instability, then I have some special sauce that takes a stab at what a stable book ought to look like and bet on the differences. For GPS I have a GPS model for the race and I compare it to the book.

elements.text: I don't use any of those things. In market based operations I just look for instability, then I have some special sauce that takes a stab at what a stable book ought to look like and bet on the differences. For GPS I have a GPS model for the race and I compare it to the book.

text: If the market is basically stable I just don't get involved - my role is to iron out the chaos a bit.

elements.text: If the market is basically stable I just don't get involved - my role is to iron out the chaos a bit.

text: <@U016TGY3676> I have also wasted lots of time looking at stuff like that - and TA. The way I look at it now is that IF it were possible to make money from some concepts from TA or something like your WOM or VWAP crossovers then everyone would be doing it. I mean its not trivial but its not hard to write something to enter on a VWAP crossover or a RSI value or any of those market indicator type things. If these were the profitable areas, then way more people would be in profit than the figures that reality suggests. I am not saying these things DON'T work but they didn't for me and I personally won't waste and more time on things like that. I say this as someone who always believed that "maths can conquer all" and that the more complicated or sophisticated a mathematical tool is, the better chance it has. After many years wasted, I no longer pursue things like this. Some of that is based on experience and wasted efforts pursuing it, and some of it talking with profitable people on social media and here in this slack.

text: Thank you all. Certainly given me a bit of direction.  So to summarise, using betfair prices as the only source of data IS possible, however modelling your own probabilities is far more lucrative IF you have a higher level understanding of maths and can build a decent model.

text: Big organisations have been in the game for 10, 20, or more years. They have built up knowledge over those years, skill sets, capital (to buy data), contacts to get information, and tried and tested techniques over that time. You can't beat them. Unless you do something different

elements.text: Big organisations have been in the game for 10, 20, or more years. They have built up knowledge over those years, skill sets, capital (to buy data), contacts to get information, and tried and tested techniques over that time. You can't beat them. Unless you do something different

text: So anything you have read on the internet has already been done. That's where you start. But then you alter your approach based on a different way of tackling things. Look for more niche markets, and try to crack those (not necessarily the big ones). In I know a guy pretty successful on Australian racing who looks at the much lower ranked meetings which are less important for the big organisations

text: This is mainly for a stats-based approach, but the general principle would be applicable to market-based approaches as well. Also don't underestimate the time it takes to "learn the ropes". It took me 10 years development of automated betting systems for big clients to be confident enough to do the same for myself. And almost 12 months in we are just starting to turn over a reasonable sum, and at this stage have banked absolutely $0 profit (what we have is actually profitable, but just winding it up at the moment). I wouldn't recommend my approach (it's actually aiming for the stars), but even scaled down it takes time

text: Going to persist with the live data for now as I'm not a massive fan of using 3rd party feeds as they can be unreliable and high maintenance. Even the GPS feed is hit and miss with false information. I've always believed that profits can be made from mug punters and will concentrate on that until it makes or breaks.

text: The way I see it - not all participants in the market are looking to make money from every bet they offer or take, or consider EV in the same way as you might do. People skew from what would be considered your "true price" for all sorts of reasons: hedging existing risk (reducing exposure to a more palatable level, maybe having operational issues etc), or doing silly "offset greening by fixed X ticks"-type things. Computation of the true price also depends on your strategy - if you are predicting the outcome of the event then you'll be applying different techniques to predicting price change over the next X seconds. This also means that not every bet has a "winner" and a "loser" - the person you were matched with may just have a different target they are wagering on, and therefore the bet can have positive expected value to both sides as the target of their forecast is diffeeent. So you don't even need "mugs" to profit on - you just need to be able to pick a reasonable target to forecast (price movement, event outcomes etc), and figure out what data can provide you with decent signals to make your forecast.

elements.text: The way I see it - not all participants in the market are looking to make money from every bet they offer or take, or consider EV in the same way as you might do. People skew from what would be considered your "true price" for all sorts of reasons: hedging existing risk (reducing exposure to a more palatable level, maybe having operational issues etc), or doing silly "offset greening by fixed X ticks"-type things. Computation of the true price also depends on your strategy - if you are predicting the outcome of the event then you'll be applying different techniques to predicting price change over the next X seconds. This also means that not every bet has a "winner" and a "loser" - the person you were matched with may just have a different target they are wagering on, and therefore the bet can have positive expected value to both sides as the target of their forecast is diffeeent. So you don't even need "mugs" to profit on - you just need to be able to pick a reasonable target to forecast (price movement, event outcomes etc), and figure out what data can provide you with decent signals to make your forecast.

text: The more participants start trying to forecast the same thing as you, the harder it gets. This is why pension funds will happily trade with high-frequency liquidity providers in financial markets - both participants are forecasting different things and so can be profitable. Sure overall it's a zero-sum game, but not necessarily on a per-trade level. If you find something exotic to forecast (e.g. forecast the likelihood of a goal happening in the next 5 mins rather than the remainder of the game), you might find other people are more willing to match with you (i.e. you'll find more opportunities to get matched at reasonable prices). Disclaimer: my setup is incredibly small compared to most ppl here as I generally target inefficiencies that I have a very high degree of certainty over (not looking for just value but LOTS of value), and these tend to be quite infrequent.
